title: Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS)
description: Estimates viability of an extremity after trauma to determine need for salvage versus empirical amputation. Evaluates four key factors: limb ischemia, patient age, shock, and injury mechanism. Originally developed for lower extremity trauma decision-making in emergency settings.

parameters.name: limb_ischemia
parameters.description: Assessment of limb perfusion and neurovascular status. Evaluates severity of ischemic injury to the affected extremity

parameters.name: ischemia_duration_hours
parameters.description: Duration of limb ischemia in hours since injury. Ischemia >6 hours doubles the ischemia component score due to increased tissue damage and reduced salvage potential

parameters.name: patient_age
parameters.description: Patient age in years. Older patients have reduced healing capacity and increased risk of complications, affecting limb salvage success rates

parameters.name: shock_status
parameters.description: Hemodynamic status and blood pressure assessment. Shock indicates systemic compromise that affects limb salvage outcomes and overall prognosis

parameters.name: injury_mechanism
parameters.description: Energy level and mechanism of injury. Higher energy injuries cause more extensive tissue damage and contamination, reducing salvage potential

result.name: mess_score
result.description: MESS score ranging from 1-14 points, where higher scores indicate increased likelihood of amputation requirement

ranges.description: Low risk for amputation with good salvage potential
ranges.interpretation: Score suggests limb salvage is likely to be successful. Proceed with aggressive limb preservation efforts including vascular repair, fracture stabilization, and soft tissue reconstruction. Close monitoring and multidisciplinary team approach recommended.

Traditional MESS threshold of 7 points. Consider patient factors, available resources, surgeon experience, and modern surgical advances. Some experts now suggest higher thresholds (8-9) due to improved surgical techniques. Requires careful clinical judgment and multidisciplinary discussion.

High MESS score suggests primary amputation may be most appropriate. Consider factors including patient comorbidities, available resources, surgical expertise, and patient preferences. Even with high scores, modern surgical advances may allow salvage in selected cases with experienced teams.

references: Johansen K, Daines M, Howey T, Helfet D, Hansen ST Jr. Objective criteria accurately predict amputation following lower extremity trauma. J Trauma. 1990 May;30(5):568-73. doi: 10.1097/00005373-199005000-00007.

Bosse MJ, MacKenzie EJ, Kellam JF, Burgess AR, Webb LX, Swiontkowski MF, et al. A prospective evaluation of the clinical utility of the lower-extremity injury-severity scores. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 2001 Jan;83(1):3-14. doi: 10.2106/00004623-200101000-00002.

Georgiadis GM, Behrens FF, Joyce MJ, Earle AS, Simmons AL. Open tibial fractures with severe soft-tissue loss. Limb salvage compared with below-the-knee amputation. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 1993 Oct;75(10):1431-41. doi: 10.2106/00004623-199310000-00003.
formula: MESS Score = Limb Ischemia points + Age points + Shock points + Injury Mechanism points. Limb Ischemia: reduced pulse (1), pulseless with paresthesias (2), cool/paralyzed/numb (3). Age: <30 years (0), 30-50 years (1), ≥50 years (2). Shock: no shock (0), transient hypotension (1), persistent hypotension (2). Injury: low energy (1), medium energy (2), high energy (3), very high energy (4). Note: Double limb ischemia points if duration >6 hours.
notes: Originally developed in 1990 for lower extremity trauma evaluation
Traditional threshold of ≥7 points suggested amputation, but modern experts suggest 8-9 due to surgical advances
Less reliable for pediatric patients and upper extremity injuries
Should be used as a prognostic guide rather than definitive decision-making tool
Recent studies question sensitivity and specificity in contemporary trauma care
Advances in vascular, orthopedic, and plastic surgery have improved limb salvage rates
Final amputation decision should involve surgeon experience, available resources, and patient factors
Patient stabilization takes priority over limb salvage decisions in acute trauma
Multidisciplinary team approach involving orthopedic, vascular, and plastic surgeons recommended
Consider patient age, comorbidities, functional expectations, and quality of life in decision-making
